_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]
Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ConocoPhillips (Formerly BP Amoco) Alliance Refinery
Risk Management Plan - 2004 Update
Executive Summary

The ConocoPhillips Alliance Refinery (Alliance) is located south of Belle Chasse, Louisiana.  Alliance processes raw crude oil into many important products including propane, diesel fuel, gasolines, jet fuel, and other intermediate refinery products.  These operations remain largely unchanged since the original Risk Management Plan (RMP) was submitted by BP Amoco to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in June of 1999.

As a company, ConocoPhillips' (CP) is committed to protecting the health, safety and environment wherever we operate.  We will not be satisfied until we succeed in eliminating all injuries, occupational illnesses, unsafe practices, and incidents of environmental harm.

To achieve these goals, Alliance?s approximately 600 employees and contractors are provided with the necessary tools (personnel training, operating and maintenance manuals, safety rules and procedures, etc.) to operate and maintain the refinery safely and in optimum condition.  The Alliance Refinery started operations in 1971 and remains one of the country's most efficient and modern refineries.  

In response to the EPA?s 1996 Risk Management Program regulations, the Alliance Refinery, then part of BP Amoco Oil Company, submitted to the Agency a Risk Management Plan (RMP) in June of 1999.  This was required of all facilities that handle certain toxic and/or flammable chemicals above pre-defined threshold amounts.  Said submittals provided the EPA with information about these chemicals, the potential risk they pose to the community, and the many ways that facilities like Alliance address and manage those risks.  

The Alliance Refinery processes, as described in the original RMP submittal, remain basically unchanged with the storage, refining and related processing of flammable chemicals still operating as described in the original submittal.  The maximum on-site inventories

of RMP-regulated substances and related information reported in the original RMP submittal have not changed significantly, except as noted below. 

In addition to flammables, the refinery stores and uses one toxic chemical, hydrogen fluoride (HF), in quantities above the RMP threshold amount.  As reported in the original RMP submittal, HF is used in the alkylation process.  

Chlorine (Cl2), which was included in the 1999 submittal as one of the refinery?s cooling water treatment chemicals, is no longer used, having been replaced by chlorine dioxide.  The latter is also an RMP-regulated chemical (threshold quantity 1,000 lb.), but no inventory is kept on site.  Instead, this chemical is generated by reacting hydrogen chloride (HCl) with sodium chlorite at or near the point of application.   Although HCl is an RMP-regulated chemical as well, it is delivered on the plant site as an aqueous solution at a concentration of 31 weight percent, which is below the RMP threshold of 37 % by weight. 

Alliance?s Risk Management Program was originally developed and implemented by BP Amoco in compliance with OSHA?s  PSM requirements (29 CFR Part 1910.119).  This Program was described and the major components were discussed in the original 1999 RMP submittal.  These components remained largely unchanged when the refinery became a part of the ConocoPhillips (CP) Company. All policies, procedures and practices were reviewed, revised and updated to reflect CP?s way of doing business, but there were no substantive changes, as CP safety policies and practices parallel those of BP Amoco?s.  

The discussion presented in the original RMP about the systems that Alliance has in place to prevent chemical release incidents from occurring included, but was not limited to the following:
1.0 Hazard Assessment
2.0 Accidental Release Prevention Program
3.0 Emergency Response Program
4.0 Alliance?s accidental release prevention and response policies
5.0 Future safety and environmental improvements

Brief updates of these elements are presented below, as necessary and applicable.

1.0 Hazard Assessment
One of the most important elements of a Risk Management Program is the hazard assessment, which provides the refinery and the public with information regarding the types and potential magnitude of the hazards at the facility.  The hazard assessment consists of two major components:  an offsite consequence analysis (OCA) and a five-year accident history.

1.1 Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA)
For the offsite consequence analysis, companies must report worse case scenarios (WCS) for each class of regulated substances -- flammable and toxic.  Alternative release scenarios (ARS) are required for flammable chemicals as a class and for each RMP toxic chemical that is present at the facility above the threshold quantity.

The Executive Summary of the original submittal included discussion of Alliance?s WCS and ARS for flammables and toxics.  The Toxics Worst Case Scenario has been updated in this submittal.  The other scenarios have not changed since the original 1999 RMP submittal (except for that of chlorine, which no longer applies), and they will not be further discussed herein.  Recent amendments to the RMP regulations (proposed at 68 FR 45125, July 31, 2003 and finalized at 69 FR 18819-18832, April 9, 2004) eliminated the requirement to discuss a facility?s OCA in the Executive Summary. 

1.2 Five Year Accident History
The Alliance refinery is proud of its safety record throughout its operating history, and in well over 5 years, it has not had any accidental releases of regulated toxic chemicals that resulted in any significant offsite health, environmental or economic effects.  

However, there were two recent incidents that involved the release of flammable chemicals which qualify as an accidental release.  Although neither of these incidents resulted in any onsite or offsite deaths or injuries, they qualify as RMP-reportable because they caused significant a

mounts of property damage inside the refinery.  

The first incident occurred on October 22, 2003, when an expander rotor blade failure caused the release of approximately 2,400 lb of a flammable hydrocarbon stream that ignited upon contact with ambient air.  There were no offsite health, environmental or economic effects.  Likewise, there were no onsite health or environmental effects, although the total on-site property damages resulting from this incident amounted to approximately $1.0 million.

The second incident occurred on February 22, 2004, when a gasket failure on a heat exchanger head caused the release of approximately 9,800 lb of flammable hydrocarbons which also ignited upon contact with the atmosphere.  The fire was quickly brought under control and extinguished by the facility?s fire brigade.  There were no onsite or offsite health or environmental effects as a result of this incident, and the onsite property damage amounted to just over $100,000 in equipment, piping and instrumentation repairs.  There were no offsite economic effects. 

2.0 Accidental Release Prevention Program Steps
Alliance developed and implemented  its process safety management (PSM) program in the early 1990's, in response to the Occupational Safety Health Administration?s (OSHA?s) promulgation of the regulations contained in 40 CFR Part 1910.119, which provide guidance to industry for developing and maintaining a Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  The RMP general accident prevention program requirements are based on the OSHA PSM standard; therefore Alliance?s PSM program also meets the requirements of the RMP regulations.  Alliance?s PSM program was summarized in the original RMP submittal and it is again summarized below (with minor changes, where and as applicable):

* Employee Participation - All employees are encouraged to actively participate in the prevention programs at Alliance Refinery.
* Process Safety Information - Alliance keeps detailed information about all

processes, chemicals, and equipment, including copies of the material safety data sheets (MSDS) for all chemicals and materials present in any significant quantities.  This allows for the safe operation and maintenance of the refinery.
* Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) - PHA's are studies that refinery teams periodically perform to make sure equipment is designed, built, and operated within safe limits. PHA?s are performed or updated for each PSM covered process at least every 5 years.
* Standard Operating Procedures (SOP?s) - Alliance Refinery has written SOP?s that address different modes of operation at the refinery and serve as a reference for experienced personnel and a training tool for new employees.  The SOP?s are certified annually.
* Training - The refinery has an on-going extensive training program that addresses both training for new employees and refresher training for all operators.  Employees are not allowed to work independently until they have demonstrated adequate knowledge in a process, and records are kept on each employee's progress.
* Contractors - Contract workers at the refinery are expected to follow the same safety procedures as ConocoPhillips employees.  Alliance evaluates contractor safety performance when selecting a contractor and monitors contractors to ensure that they are working safely.
* Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) - Alliance performs PSSR's when there is an addition or change to any of the operating units at the refinery.  This ensures that the change is compatible with the unit design and provides a safety check prior to startup of equipment.
* Mechanical Integrity - The mechanical integrity program at Alliance Refinery ensures that existing equipment is in working order and that new equipment is suitable for its intended use.
* Safe Work Practices - Alliance Refinery has many safe work practices in place to ensure safety.  These include plant security, hot work and confined space permits and procedures, and procedures to s

ecure equipment (Lock-out/Tag-out) before maintenance is performed.  The safe practice procedures are reviewed at least annually to ensure that they are current and complete and that the necessary changes are timely made to reflect changes in the process, chemicals, technology, equipment and/or operating practices.
* Management of Change (MOC) - The MOC system at Alliance Refinery ensures that all significant equipment, process or operating changes are technically and operationally sound and that they are consistent with ConocoPhillips? practices and procedures.
* Incident Investigation - Alliance Refinery promptly investigates all incidents and near misses at the refinery.  The findings are issued in an incident investigation report and are discussed with operating, technical and administrative personnel.  This provides a mechanism to learn from accidents and improve safety.
* Compliance Audits - Every three years, Alliance Refinery conducts an audit to make sure that all of the safety programs are in place and functioning properly.  In addition to audits, Alliance conducts in-house inspections that are a part of a monthly Health & Safety Compliance Evaluation Program.

In addition to the General Accidental Release Prevention Program elements, Alliance has safety features on the refinery's process units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of, or mitigate a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Detection
- Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms
- Toxic gas detectors with alarms
- Level indicators and alarms (where necessary)
- Pressure indicators and alarms (where applicable)
        
Release Containment/Control
- Process relief valves that discharge to a flare system to capture and incinerate episodic releases        
- Scrubbers to neutralize chemical releases
- Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated)
- Automated shutdown systems f

or specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)
- Vessels to permit partial removal of the process inventory in the event of a release (e.g., dump tanks)
- Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases
- Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater pump)
- Atmospheric relief devices

Release Mitigation
- Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
- Deluge systems for specific equipment
- Trained emergency response personnel
- Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)

3.0 Emergency Response Program
The Alliance Refinery maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  This program is essentially the same as that described in the original 1999 RMP submittal.

The program consists of procedures for responding to releases or incidents involving flammable, combustible, toxic or otherwise hazardous substances (whether regulated or not), including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including but not limited to: 1) prompt identification and assessment of incident and its magnitude; 2) formulation and implementation of the appropriate plan of action to minimize and/or mitigate the consequences and effects; 3) as necessary, promptly administer proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, 4) evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, 5) notification of local authorities, community emergency responders and the public if a significant release occurs, and 6) post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. 

The Alliance Refinery has its own emergency response team that covers fire response, hazardous materials response, and first aid response on a 24-hour basis.  The emergency response team trains regu

larly to maintain their readiness and preparedness to tackle any incident involving any of the flammable, hazardous and toxic chemicals and materials handled by the refinery, as well as other occupational incidents and emergencies. 

In addition, the Alliance Refinery has procedures that address maintenance, inspection and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  

The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to refinery processes or other refinery facilities.  Changes to the emergency response program are administered through the Management of Change process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in such changes.

The overall emergency response program for the Alliance Refinery is coordinated with the Belle Chasse Fire Department and the Plaquemines Parish Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes close liaison with refinery emergency response teams and periodic meetings between local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The Alliance Refinery has 24-hour communications capability with appropriate officials and emergency response agencies.  This provides a means of notifying the public in a timely manner, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident, if and as necessary.  Alliance conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the refinery?s emergency response team, the LEPC and other emergency response agencies.  Alliance also provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of flammable, toxic and hazardous substances that are present in the refinery.

4.0 Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies
Alliance Refinery maintains the same high level of commitment to Health, Safety a

nd the Environment that has been set forth by ConocoPhillips at all of the company?s facilities.  Every CP employee is responsible for operating within strict Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) guidelines.  As a company, CP continues to minimize the environmental and health impact of its operations by reducing waste, by minimizing emissions and discharges, and by using energy more efficiently.  CP?s corporate policy is to eliminate all injuries, occupational illnesses, unsafe practices, and incidents of environmental harm from our activities. 

Safety Performance
Alliance?s commitment to the safety of people and protection of the environment has been demonstrated through the many awards the Refinery has received and the achieved milestones.  Alliance Refinery has received numerous awards from various organizations such as the National Petroleum Refiners Association, National Safety Council and Greater New Orleans Industrial Education Council.  Additionally, the Alliance Refinery has reached several milestones including 5 million safe work hours as a business unit and 3 million safe work hours for ConocoPhillips employees.  In an effort to continue to improve our safety performance, several new programs have been established which include a Management Audit Program and a Near Miss Reporting Program.  Finally, the newly established Joint Health and Safety Committee was formed to address any concerns which may arise from the work force.

Environmental Performance

As part of Alliance?s environmental policy, we are committed to the protection and respect of the environment in which the refinery operates.  We operate in such a manner as to minimize the refinery's impact on the environment while competitively producing quality petroleum products.  Evidence of our commitment is in the many environmental programs we have in place at the refinery and the initiatives that we have taken to make the Alliance Refinery an efficiently run and environmentally friendly refinery.

Environmental emissions from the refinery have declined significantly throughout the last decade due to ConocoPhillips? strong commitment to the environment and with improved technology that is now available.  Since 1992, the Alliance Refinery has reduced emissions 95%.  It is Alliance?s goal to identify all areas within the refinery where appropriate feasible technology can be applied to minimize environmental releases even further in the future.  Evidence of this is that several times in the recent past, the Alliance Refinery has earned special citations from the Governor of Louisiana's Environmental Leadership Awards program for its work to prevent pollution.  Alliance?s commitment is further demonstrated by the investment of approximately $200 million since 1988 to complete a series of environmental projects to not only comply with new environmental regulations but also to improve environmental performance.  

In addition, in December of 1998, Alliance Refinery received a coveted international certification, marking the first time a U.S. oil refinery has ever earned the "ISO 14001" title.  ISO 14001 is a set of rigorous environmental standards developed by the International Standards Organization (ISO).  The ISO 14001 standard provides a guide for companies in measuring the thoroughness and effectiveness of their environmental management system.

5.0 Future Safety and Environmental Improvements 
Everybody who works for CP, anywhere, is responsible for getting Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) performance right.  Good HSE performance is critical to the success of our business and is strongly promoted by the company's top executives worldwide. 
 
We will continue to drive down the environmental and health impact of our operations by reducing waste, emissions and discharges, and using energy efficiently.  
 
Our business plans include measurable HSE targets.  We are all committed to meeting them.
